content: The House and Senate passed their respective National Defense Authorization Acts for Fiscal Year 2017, containing provisions affecting military personnel. A conference committee was convened to reconcile differences between the two versions. After the House and Senate passed their respective National Defense Authorization Acts for Fiscal Year 2017, a conference committee was convened to resolve differences. The President signed the final bill into law on December 23, 2016. This report highlights selected personnel-related issues of congressional and constituent interest, with contact information for CRS analysts provided. The report provides detailed background information and analysis of issues related to the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2016. Contact information for CRS analysts is included for each issue discussed. Some issues were previously addressed in the FY2016 NDAA and other reports. Authorized active duty end-strengths for FY2001 are also mentioned. Authorized active duty end-strengths for FY2001 were set for Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force. Congress increased Army and Marine Corps personnel in response to wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, but later reversed due to troop withdrawals and budget constraints. Air Force and Navy end-strengths have been declining since 2001. In 2011, U.S. forces drawdown in Afghanistan began in 2012 due to budget constraints. End-strengths for Air Force and Navy have been declining since 2001. FY2017 budget proposed lowering end-strengths for all services, with the House approving higher end-strengths than the Administration's request, notably for the Army. The House-proposed increase in end-strength for the Army, Marine Corps, and Air Force was notable, with a reduction for the Navy. The final bill set minimum end-strengths equal to authorized levels for FY2017. The overall authorized end-strength of the Selected Reserves has declined by about 6% over the past 15 years, with reductions in Navy Reserve strength being a significant factor. Authorized end-strengths for the Selected Reserve in FY2016 and FY2017 are shown in Figure 2. For FY2017, the Administration requested a reduction in authorized Selected Reserves end-strength for four reserve components and increases for two. The House bill proposed increasing the Army National Guard's end-strength to 350,000 and the Army Reserve's end-strength to 205,000. The House bill proposed increasing the Army National Guard's end-strength to 350,000 and the Army Reserve's end-strength to 205,000. This is in response to concerns about the overall cost of military personnel and the need to recruit and retain high-quality personnel for the all-volunteer military. The military pay raise is a topic of interest due to the need to recruit and retain high-quality personnel for the all-volunteer military. Section 1009 of Title 37 US Code provides for an annual increase in basic pay indexed to the Employment Cost Index. The increase for 2017 is set at 2.1% unless Congress or the President specifies otherwise. The President can specify an alternative pay adjustment under 37 U.S.C. §1009(e) instead of the annual increase in basic pay indexed to the Employment Cost Index. In the past three years, the President set the pay raise below the ECI by invoking this authority. The FY2017 President's Budget requested a 1.6% military pay raise, lower than the statutory formula of 2.1%. The House bill aimed to enforce the statutory formula, resulting in a 2.1% pay raise for all servicemembers. The enacted bill specified a 2.1% pay raise for all servicemembers, effective January 1, 2017, waiving the automatic adjustment to basic pay. The pay raise process for servicemembers includes government-provided housing or a housing allowance called Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH), based on paygrade, geographic location, and other factors. The housing allowance for those in the United States is known as Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH), determined by paygrade, geographic location, and dependency status to provide suitable accommodation. BAH rates vary by location but ensure servicemembers of similar rank and family status can afford comparable housing regardless of duty location. The Senate bill proposed changes to how Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) is calculated, focusing on geographic location and paygrade rather than dependents. It would base BAH on actual housing expenditures up to a maximum amount for a given location/paygrade, altering how it is paid to servicemembers who share living arrangements. The Senate bill proposed changes to how Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) is calculated, focusing on geographic location and paygrade rather than dependents. It would base BAH on actual housing expenditures up to a maximum amount for a given location/paygrade, altering how it is paid to servicemembers who share living arrangements by reducing the allowance based on the number of people sharing the quarters. The new formula would apply to certain members of the Armed Forces starting on January 1, 2018. Members of the Armed Forces affected by the new provision starting January 1, 2018 include those who first receive basic pay on or after that date, certain reserve and retired personnel called to active duty, and servicemembers who lose eligibility for BAH after December 31, 2017. The Secretary of Defense would need to submit proposed regulations for this provision to Congress. The Senate provision requires the Secretary of Defense to submit proposed regulations for a new pay structure to Congress by March 31, 2017. The enacted bill mandates a report on transitioning to a single-salary pay system by March 1, 2017, eliminating Basic Allowance for Housing and Basic Allowance for Subsistence. The conference report aims to recruit and retain a high-quality All-Volunteer Force by eliminating Basic Allowance for Housing and Basic Allowance for Subsistence. The provision acknowledges the evolution of BAH over the past 20 years and its original purpose to provide a housing benefit for servicemembers in high-cost areas without government-provided quarters. The government is planning to transition to a salary system that aligns the payment of housing allowance with its use as compensation for military members and their families. The military is transitioning to a salary system to align housing allowance payment with compensation, as outlined in the National Defense Authorization Act for FY2016. The military retirement system underwent changes in the National Defense Authorization Act for FY2016, including reducing the retired pay multiplier, adding a 401k-type element, allowing for a partial lump-sum payment, and introducing continuation pay as a retention incentive. These changes will take effect on January 1, 2018, for new servicemembers and those with 12 years or less of service. The military retirement system changes, including a reduced pay multiplier and introduction of continuation pay as a retention incentive, have raised concerns about retaining certain occupational specialties. Active duty military and veterans closely monitor these changes. The military retirement system changes include authorization for continuation pay at 8 to 12 years of service in exchange for a 3-year commitment, providing flexibility for targeted retention incentives based on specific military specialties. The enacted bill includes changes to pay based on retention trends for specific military specialties, amending procedures for calculating continuation pay minimums for active and reserve component members. It ensures that reserve component members on active duty receive the same minimum pay as active duty members when accepting continuation pay. Additionally, there is a provision regarding default contributions to the TSP being to a Roth plan. The Senate bill proposed default contributions to the TSP should be to a Roth plan, which is beneficial for young, low-income individuals. However, this provision was not adopted. Section 631 of the Senate bill amends 10 U.S.C. §1409 to allow cadets, midshipmen, and reservists a 30-day election period for the new retirement system following commissioning or transfer to active duty. The Uniformed Services Former Spouses' Protection Act (USFSPA) allows state courts to divide military retired pay in divorce cases and provides certain former spouses with military benefits. The law was enacted in 1982 and has been modified over the years. Contact CRS for more information. The USFSPA allows state courts to divide military retired pay in divorce cases. Up to 50% of a servicemember's disposable military retired pay may be divisible by the court. Proposed changes would use pay grade and years of service at the time of a divorce court order. The USFSPA allows state courts to divide military retired pay in divorce cases, with proposed changes to use pay grade and years of service at the time of a divorce court order. The enacted bill authorizes this change and includes cost-of-living adjustments in spousal payments, without affecting prior divorce settlements. A military retiree may have a portion of their monthly retired pay withheld to provide a survivor benefit to a surviving spouse or eligible recipients after their death, known as the Survivor Benefit Plan (SBP). The survivor's payment through SBP is usually 55% of the retired basic pay the member would have been eligible to receive. The Survivor Benefit Plan (SBP) provides a survivor's payment of 55% of the retired basic pay to eligible recipients. Previously, servicemembers who died on active duty received 75% of their basic pay, while reservists who died during inactive-duty training received less based on their years of service. This discrepancy was addressed in the FY2017 NDAA. Surviving spouses may receive annuities from both DOD and VA. The FY2017 NDAA addressed the reduction of SBP payments for surviving spouses who receive DIC from VA. The SSIA offsets this reduction and was set to expire at the end of FY2017. Sections 642, 643, 646, and 648 of the enacted bill amend provisions in Title 10, United States Code related to SBP treatment. The enacted bill amends Title 10, United States Code to eliminate differential treatment under the SBP for reserve and active component members who die from an injury during inactive-duty training. It also allows DOD to withhold SBP payments from Combat Related Special Compensation when retired pay is insufficient to cover the premiums. Section 646 of the enacted bill extends authority to pay SSIA until May 31, 2018 and requires a report on affected individuals. Nearly 65,000 surviving spouses are estimated to receive SSIA in FY2018. Section 648 mandates an independent assessment of SBP by a federally funded research center and submission of a report with recommendations. The Secretary is required to conduct an independent assessment of the Survivor Benefit Plan (SBP) through a federally funded research center and submit a report with recommendations to the House and Senate Armed Services Committees. The report will evaluate the effectiveness of the SBP for survivors of servicemembers, compare benefits with other government and private sector employees, and explore the feasibility of providing survivor benefits through alternative insurance products. TRICARE is a DOD-administered health benefits program covering active duty servicemembers, retirees, and their families. The Administration's FY2017 Budget proposed changes to health care enrollment fees. Feasibility of survivor benefits through alternative insurance products is being explored. The Administration's FY2017 Budget proposed changes to TRICARE health care enrollment fees, including replacing current options with TRICARE Select and TRICARE Preferred, introducing new enrollment fees, deductibles, co-payments, and catastrophic caps. Additionally, there were proposals for increased pharmacy co-pays for retirees and military family members. The Administration's FY2017 Budget proposed changes to TRICARE health care enrollment fees, including introducing TRICARE Select and TRICARE Preferred, new enrollment fees, deductibles, co-payments, and catastrophic caps. The proposal also included increased pharmacy co-pays for retirees and military family members, with grandfathering for Medicare-enrolled retirees already receiving TRICARE benefits. Additionally, the proposal aimed to reduce TRICARE for Life expenditures by funding it through the Medicare Eligible Retiree Health Care Fund. The MERHCF covers future medical treatment costs for Medicare eligible uniformed services retirees and dependents through TRICARE for Life. The FY2017 contribution per servicemember is $4,252 for active duty and $1,723 for reserve component members. CBO estimates show proposed TRICARE changes could save DOD billions and increase Medicare spending. The new TRICARE proposals would save $2.8 billion, with the TRICARE for Life enrollment fee saving $1.4 billion and the consolidation of TRICARE plans costing DOD $0.2 billion. The proposals would also increase Medicare spending by $0.4 billion.
